ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Vocabulary: colloquial sayings, idioms, terms related to film and cinematography, words to use in a debate, words and format used in a formal letter; Practice with speaking: describing a character, summarizing and analyzing movies; A little bit of grammar; Reading comprehension. We discussed deep topics about society, forms of government, the meaning of life, familial relationships. Also get insight into some classic Chinese movies!

I was able to expand my Chinese vocabulary, learning new idioms, colloquialisms, etc. Through watching a wide-ranging variety of movies, I was also exposed to other aspects of Chinese culture and history, from Chinese attitudes towards mysticism to ideals of filial piety.
I improved my Chinese writing skills, expanded my vocabulary, and practiced presenting.
I got a lot of practice speaking, writing, reading, and listening to Chinese. This course also helped me increase my knowledge of Chinese culture and vocabulary.
Chinese culture, vocab, writing skills, speaking skills
A deeper understanding of Chinese culture, politics, and history. Vastly improved writing and speaking skills, and reading and listening skills to a lesser extent.
chinese language and culture
Advanced my Chinese speaking, listening, and reading abilities

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: engaging class activities, a variety of forms language proficiency. Weaknesses: answering homework questions during the movie makes the movie take a long time
There isn't a course textbook. It was great to be able to tailor my learning to what I wanted to gain out of the class. The assignments were time-consuming and at times repetitive.

I think this course was structured pretty well! I really liked the discussion-based activites. I think the pace of movie-watching could be faster, or some movies could be switched out, or some movie-associated activities could be changed, to ensure we are continuing to discuss fresh content.
I loved the class! It was such a great way to learn Chinese!

The films that were selected were great, and the discussions + accompanying materials really helped improve my Chinese ability. Liang Laoshi did a fantastic job of cultivating a friendly and supportive classroom environment, which extended to the class community itself. The only weakness is that some weeks' workloads were intense, but Liang Laoshi was very receptive to adjusting due dates.

Strengths: highly engaging, great professor, really good movies
Weaknesses: homework was a little bit too much at first

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! The movies span a wide range of genres and include classics. All of them are fun to watch, deep, and thought-provoking. The workload is light and very manageable. Hand-writing of characters is not required, so if you are good at typing and speaking, this class is perfect.

If you are proficient in your Mandarin listening and speaking skills, this course is helpful in improving your Chinese writing. Professor Liang provides assignments that, step-by-step, help you expand your vocabulary and write more in-depth analyses of Chinese media.
Yes! It's a great course to practice and grow your Chinese skills.
Yes I would! It was a fun and interesting class.
Yes! It was the best Chinese class I have ever taken. Not only is it fun, but I also learned so much

Yes! Taking any Chinese class with Liang Laoshi is fantastic, and the unique student-led structure of the class made it a great bonding and educational experience. One of the best, if not the best Chinese electives you can take.
Yes, great professor and good way to practice chinese

yes, i would recommend this course to students who love watching movies and learning Chinese in a less textbook regimented structure; they'll get a lot of freedom in choosing how they want to respond to prompts, essays, and even choose their own movies to watch
